bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Thomas Dublin is a United States Social Historian with an interest in gender, race, ethnicity and class in the working-class experience. He has focused on both the Industrial Revolution in nineteenth-century New England and deindustrialization in the Middle Atlantic region in the twentieth century. He is a Distinguished Professor at the State University of New York at Binghamton and author of Women at Work: The Transformation of Work and Community in Lowell, Massachusetts, 1826-1860 (Columbia University Press, 1979), Women and Power in American History, (Prentice-Hall, 2008, third edition) co-edited with Kathryn Kish Sklar, and many other works. Professor Dublin received his Ph.D. at Columbia University.
